quoteFirst: Curious conventions grew up, and at certain hours of the day and, less commonly, of the night, there was a kind of informal armistice. In one section the hour of
quoteLast: was regarded as consecrated to "private business," and certain places indicated by a flag were regarded as out of bounds by the snipers on both sides. On many occasions working parties toiled with pick and shovel within talking distance of one another, and, although it was, of course, never safe to presume upon immunity, they usually forbore to interfere with one another.
title: Leaves from a Field Note-Book
author: Morgan, J. H. (John Hartman), 1876-1955

quoteLast: . At nine exactly it will be all over with me. A dog barks outside--one, two--then is silent for a little and--one, two, three.

quoteFirst: From
quoteLast: the physician goes his round of visits, accompanied by his assistants. He passes from bed to bed, feels pulses, looks at tongues, prescribes medicines, and so forth.
title: Old and New Paris: Its History, Its People, and Its Places, v. 2
author: Edwards, H. Sutherland (Henry Sutherland), 1828-1906

quoteFirst: We are like the people at Cremorne waiting for the fireworks to begin; and I really do believe that if this continues much longer, the most cowardly will welcome the bombs as a relief from the oppressive ennui. Few regiments are seen now during the day marching through the streets--they are most of them either on the ramparts or outside them. From
quoteLast: there is a military movement, as regiments come and go, on and off duty. In the courtyard of the Louvre several regiments of Mobiles are kept under arms all night, ready to march to any point which may be seriously attacked.
title: Diary of the Besieged Resident in Paris
author: Labouchere, Henry Du Pré, 1831-1912

quoteFirst: At
quoteLast: , as we had closed to within 20,000 yards of the rear ship, the Battle Cruisers manœuvred to keep on a line of bearing so that guns would bear, and _Lion_ fired a single shot, which fell short. The enemy at this time were in single line ahead, with Light Cruisers ahead and a large number of Destroyers on their starboard beam.
title: The Grand Fleet, 1914-1916
author: Jellicoe, John Rushworth, 1859-1935

quoteFirst: At Nash, on 15th, eleven Cuckoos passed N.W. from 1 to 3 p.m., calm, mist. On 16th, five passed N.W. from
quoteLast: , light E.S.E. air, mist. On May 4th, four passed S.W. at 9 a.m., gentle E.S.E. breeze, mist, rain.
title: Report on the Migration of Birds in the Spring and Autumn of 1881. Third Report
author: Harvie-Brown, J. A. (John Alexander), 1844-1916; Barrington, Richard Manliffe, 1849-1915; Cordeaux, John, 1831-1899; Kermode, P. M. C. (Philip Moore Callow), 1855?-1932; More, Alexander Goodman, 1830-1895

quoteFirst: When Marion went back to college the other four continued to amuse themselves by gossiping daily over the wire; but gradually, as the novelty of the thing wore away, they became less eager to use their lately acquired powers and so, at the period of this story, the click of an instrument was seldom heard except when there was some question to ask or some real news to communicate. By concerted arrangement they were all alert to a “call” between six and seven in the evening and from
quoteTime: eight to nine in the morning
quoteLast: s, but their trained ears now recognized the click-click! if they were anywhere within hearing of it.
title: Phoebe Daring: A Story for Young Folk
author: Baum, L. Frank (Lyman Frank), 1856-1919; Nuyttens, Josef Pierre, 1885-1960 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: And taking out his watch, Lord Rex struck a vesuvian in order to learn the time. It was exactly
quoteLast: , and at nine, sharp, the _Princess_ was to weigh her anchor. The moment for action had come. Now, what was the wisest thing to do? One point seemed certain--it was useless for both boats to wait longer.
title: A Girton Girl
author: Edwards, Annie, -1896

title: The Passaic Flood of 1903

quoteFirst: The shelling was particularly heavy from
quoteTime: eight to nine in the morning
quoteLast: , and again from one to two. As the wooden houses caught fire, and the work-people were driven out in helpless crowds from their barracks by the crash of shells, the soldiers came crowding in with rifle and sword, and met with little organized resistance.
